contentOne.title: What is this?
body:
With the rise of a new foe, humanity suffers an everlasting pandemic, spreading like wildfire with the slyness of a fox.
The said pandemic has caused many world leaders to take action, ceasing the rights of everyone's ability to roam freely on land, sea and sky.
The actions were solely to deter the uprising of the new enemy, COVID-19, however, the effects that it would take on some or many individuals were dreary.
With the lack of communication and interaction with those of the same species, humans laid dormant in their homes, taking a toll on those who find it sickening.
This directly impacts their mental health, giving them issues such as depression, anxiety and stress.
As to recognise those who are victims to the mental impact the enemy has brought, we developed a web app that uses DASS-21 so people can assess their mental health easily.

contentTwo.title: What is DASS-21?
body:
The Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale - 21 Items (DASS-21) is a set of three self-report scales designed to measure the emotional states of depression, anxiety and stress.
Each of the three DASS-21 scales contains 7 items, divided into subscales with similar content.
The depression scale assesses dysphoria, hopelessness, devaluation of life, self-deprecation, lack of interest / involvement, anhedonia and inertia.
The anxiety scale assesses autonomic arousal, skeletal muscle effects, situational anxiety, and subjective experience of anxious affect.
The stress scale assesses difficulty relaxing, nervous arousal, and being easily upset / agitated, irritable / over-reactive and impatient.
Scores for depression, anxiety and stress are calculated by summing the scores for the relevant items.

contentThree.title: Is DASS-21 reliable?
body: The answer is; Yes definitely. Below are a few articles to prove that DASS is valid and reliable.

articles: Lovibond SH, Lovibond PF. Manual for the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales. 2. Sydney: Psychology Foundation of Australia; 1995.

Lovibond PF, Lovibond SH. The structure of negative emotional states: comparison of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS) with the Beck Depression and Anxiety Inventories. Behav Res Ther. 1995;33(3):335–343.

Ng F, Trauer T, Dodd S, Callaly T, Campbell S, Berk M. The validity of the 21‐item version of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales as a routine clinical outcome measure. Acta Neuropsychiatrica. 2007;19(5):304–310
Brown TA, Chorpita BF, Korotitsch W, Barlow DH. Psychometric properties of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS) in clinical samples. Behav Res Ther. 1997;35(1):79–89.

Antony MM, Bieling PJ, Cox BJ, Enns MW, Swinson RP. Psychometric properties of the 42-item and 21-item versions of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales in clinical groups and a community sample. Psychol Assess. 1998;10(2):176–181.

Henry JD, Crawford JR. The short-form version of the Depression Anxiety Stress Scales (DASS-21): Construct validity and normative data in a large non-clinical sample. Br J Clin Psychol. 2005;44:227–239.

rulesPage.title: Rules
rules: Please read the questions and pick an answer that best suits your condition for the PAST WEEK
There are no right and wrong answers, so don't worry about it
DON'T take too long answering any of the questions

questions.text: I found it hard to wind down
I was aware of dryness of my mouth
I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all
I experienced breathing difficulty (e.g excessively rapid breathing, breathlessness in the absence of physical exertion)
I found it difficult to work up the initiative to do things
I tended to over-react to situations
I experienced trembling (e.g in the hands)
I felt that I was using a lot of nervous energy
I was worried about situations in which I might panic and make a fool of myself
I felt that I had nothing to look forward to
I found myself getting agitated
I found it difficult to relax
I felt down-hearted and blue
I was intolerant of anything that kept me from getting on with what I was doing
I felt I was close to panic
I was unable to become enthusiastic about anything
I felt I wasn't worth much as a person
I felt that I was rather touchy
I was aware of the action of my heart in the absence of physical exertion (e.g sense of heart rate increase, heart missing a beat)
I felt scared without any good reason
I felt that life was meaningless

depression:
Your depression level is normal. That's a good thing! But you have to maintain it.
It is best that you take measures in preventing yourself from attaining depression.
Measures such as exercising regularly, avoiding toxic people and getting plenty of sleep.
Wish you the best of luck!
Your depression level is mild. That's a stage higher than normal.
But don't worry, it'll be alright. Just make sure to eat well and maintain a healthy weight.
A healthy mind comes with a healthy body. Also, be sure to interact more with your friends and maintain a healthy relationship.
Your depression level seems to be moderate...for now.
It's recommended that you stop doing activities such as communicating with the wrong people,
eating an unbalanced diet and thinking about negative thoughts. Put a halt to anything that can
cause your depression to grow. Also, be sure to make some time for yourself to talk with yourself.
Your depression level has reached the stage of severe. That is not good.
Small efforts to undo it will be futile. It is highly suggested that you talk with those
who you can trust such as friends or loved ones about your ordeal or consult a medical professional
such as a counselor or a therapist. Please do so if you wish for help.
Your depression level is extremely severe. It is a must that you come in contact with a medical professional for assistance.
If you're having any suicidal thoughts, please refrain from doing anything rash and contact your local suicide hotline.
Remember, you are not alone.
anxiety:
Your anxiety level is normal. That's good because occasional anxiety is completely OK.
Anxiety is a normal human experience. Just don't let it stretch too far out.
As long as you take measures to do so, you'll be alright. Wish you all the best!
Your anxiety level is mild. That's a bit over the average but you'll be alright as long as
you make sure that it doesn't go out of your control. Write down your thoughts and take a walk
from time to time. Do something that can calm you down or go to places with a relaxing atmosphere.
Your anxiety level is moderate. It's highly suggested that you start taking precautions such as
trying supplements, changing your diet and questioning your thought patterns. Your anxiety
should be handled properly to prevent it from furthur growing to a scale that you might find difficult to manage.
Your anxiety level is severe. It's gone up to the stage where it may disrupt your daily activities.
You should try and focus on using better strategies for coping with anxiety such as identifying and
learning to manage your triggers and adopting cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Of course, you can
always ask your doctor about medications.
Your anxiety level is extremely severe. At this point, your anxiety may start to become harmful.
 
There are times anxiety can get serious and turn into anxiety attacks that initially feel manageable and then gradually build up over a few hours.
Worst case scenario, you can experience an anxiety and panic attack simultaneously. Identifying the signs
is one thing but it is better that you seek attention from a medical professional.
stress:
Your stress level is normal. Stress is a normal psychological and physical reaction
to positive or negative situations in your life, such as a new job or the death of a loved one.
Just make sure that it doesn't become more than you can handle.
Do that and you'll be able to maintain your normal stress level for a long time.
Wish you all the success!
Your stress level is mild. A bit higher than what's normal but not strong enough to make an impact
on your daily life. Some day-to-day stress is normal but we all need to know when to close our eyes
and take a deep breath when we feel tension rising. Remember to take care of yourself with plenty of sleep,
limiting alcohol and stimulants and giving yourself a break when you feel stressed out.
Your stress level is moderate. It's recommended that you start taking steps to cope with stress such as
balancing work and home time, carving out hobby time and resting when you really need it. It's to make
sure that your stress doesn't reach the level where it can start to harm you and effect those around you.
All in all, take better care of yourself. You can't take care of other matters if you can't even take care of yourself.
Your stress level is severe. It's time you start taking things seriously and really put an effort to relieve yourself.
Connect with supportive people who can listen and help you. Perhaps, if the oppurtunity arises, take a vacation
and get away from it all. Remember to go easy on yourself and things around you. Listen to some music for that extra
stress relief and refer to a doctor for medication.
Your stress level is extremely severe. You probably experience headaches from time to time and a decrease
in energy along with insomnia. Your stress has reached the stage where it's now harmful to yourself and it may
effect others as well. It's best that you stop taking tobacco and stimulants if you are and seek attention
from a medical professional.
